title: Understanding the Problem
text: To solve a system of equations using the inverse of a matrix, you first need to express the system as a matrix equation. If we have three equations like we do here, our goal is to express these in the form AX $$=$$ B, where A is a coefficient matrix, X is the variable matrix, and B is the constant matrix.

title: Forming the Coefficient Matrix
text: Look at the coefficients of (x, $$y$$, z) in each of the equations. Form a matrix by placing these coefficients into rows. What does the 3x3 coefficient matrix A look like?

title: Forming the Constant Matrix
text: Identify the constants on the right side of each equation and place them in a column matrix. What does the constant matrix B look like?

title: Applying Inverse Matrix
text: To solve for X, we use the equation X $$=$$ $$A^{-1} B$$. This means we need to find the inverse of A. However, not all matrices have inverses. Can you think of a situation or condition a matrix must meet to have an inverse?

title: Calculating the Inverse
text: For a 3x3 matrix, the inverse calculation involves finding the determinant and then using it along with a matrix of minors, cofactors, and adjugate of A. Remember, a matrix only has an inverse if its determinant is non-zero. Try calculating the determinant of A first.

title: Checking the Determinant
text: Using matrix A, calculate the determinant using the formula det(A) $$=$$ $$a(ei-fh)$$ - $$b(di-fg)$$ + $$c(dh-eg)$$. What is the determinant of the matrix A?
